awd_titl_txt: ELT Collaborative research:  Evolutionary and ecological responses of small mammal communities to habitat and climate change over the last 5 million years
awd_abstract_narration:
Technical description: The goal of this project is to test three models of faunal change in response to biotic and abiotic forcings during the transition to the modern grassland ecosystem in the Great Plains over the last 4.5 My: the Red Queen, the Court Jester, and the Equilibrium Theory of Island Biogeography. In doing so, we will answer four specific research questions: 1) Do long-term changes in local habitat or climate control taxonomic diversity dynamics? 2) Does climate change associated with the onset of Northern Hemisphere glaciation at 2.5 Ma impact diversity dynamics or the ecological structure of communities? 3) How do catastrophic events (major ashfalls) impact diversity dynamics and ecological structure of communities? 4) How are immigrant species accommodated in the ecological structure of the contemporary community? We will analyze diversity dynamics with an existing database of species occurrences in the Meade Basin, SW Kansas in relation to reconstructions of local paleoecology, paleoenvironment, and paleoclimate.  We will characterize ecological structure of communities with body sizes estimated from tooth dimensions and trophic categories reconstructed from carbon isotope compositions of tooth enamel using laser ablation isotope ratio mass spectrometry and a novel combination of morphometric analyses based on high resolution microCT scans. Interpretation of paleodiet proxies will be constrained by isotopic and morphometric analyses of modern species with known diets and habitats from existing museum collections and live trapping in grasslands around Meade, KS. Paleoenvironmental and paleoclimatic reconstructions will be based on a comprehensive suite of proxies measured on paleosol carbonates and bulk sediment samples collected in stratigraphic association with known fossil sites and major ashfalls: carbon isotope ratios of bulk organic matter, carbon and hydrogen isotope ratios of leaf wax n-alkanes, lignin phenol ratios, plant phytolith assemblages, carbonate clumped isotope paleothermometry, and paleosol elemental geochemistry and mineralogy. Paleoclimate proxies and isotopic data will be compared to output of regional scale, isotope-enabled paleoclimate simulations under various forcings. Finally, we will construct ecological niche models for modern mammal species and genera in the region and use paleoclimate model output to test how climate change may have forced range shifts and taxonomic turnover in the Meade record.

Non-technical description: Understanding the origin of modern communities is a fundamental goal of ecology, but reconstructing the history of communities that include species with stratigraphic durations on the scale of hundreds of thousands to millions of years necessarily requires data from the fossil record. Similarly, inferences about the paleoecology of past communities are most robust when informed by data from both living and fossil populations of extant species. Despite the logical connections between ecology and paleoecology, relatively few studies have bridged the gaps in the characteristic observational timescales and methodologies of these disciplines to achieve a comprehensive view of the long-term evolution of specific modern communities.  The need to bridge these disciplinary gaps is increasingly pressing in the face of anthropogenic climate change and uncertainty about the magnitude and direction of responses by local communities. This project will examine the ecological, environmental, and climatic context of the origin of the modern small mammal community in the grasslands of the central USA over the last five million years. We will test the effects of both biological and non-biological factors on long-term taxonomic turnover and ecological change in a stratigraphic sequence of local communities using a combination of ecomorphology, biogeochemistry, paleoclimate modeling, and biogeography. This project will link evolution, ecology, and paleoecology with biogeochemistry to trace the emergence of a modern ecosystem over geological time.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the role of environmental change during the last ~5 million years on small mammal (mostly rodent) population change and evolution in southwestern Kansas. Previous paleontological studies on the ancient soils preserved in the area have yielded a wealth of rodent fossils that span the last 5 million years of time, and show how the modern community of rodents has evolved to be what it is today. However, it has been hard to determine how and why those rodent communities changed through time to what they are now. Community change in animal groups can be driven by internal factors, such as competition for resources from other animals that move into a region, and by external factors, like ecosystem changes resulting from changes in temperature or water availability.

During this same span of time, the region transitioned into a grassland environment that was dominated by grasses that use a particular type of photosynthesis called C4 photosynthesis. This transition to C4-dominated grasslands occurred in many other tropical and temperate regions on earth at similar times, but the reason for this change is not yet understood. Previous workers have suggested that changes in CO2 levels in the atmosphere, changes in temperature, or increased aridity or fire frequency may have favored C4 grasses. Therefore in addition to testing the role of external factors in driving animal community changes, our study was designed to explore the drivers of grassland changes as well.

To address these questions, we collected samples for geochemical, sedimentological and ancient vegetation analysis. We used multiple different geochemical tools to reconstruct temperature, precipitation and aridity changes, and to track the relative proportion of C4 grasses through time. We also collected samples to look at phytoliths preserved in the sediment, which are microscopic, silica-based components of plants; we used this information to reconstruct the vegetation and climate through time from the same sediments that host the small mammal fossils. This approach allows us to compare any changes that occur in the fossil communities, vegetation, or climate over the past 5 million years.

There are multiple outcomes from this research that fall into two categories: insights and implications for the tools we use to reconstruct ancient environmental change, and insights into the role of climate on vegetation and small mammal communities. For the tools, we learned that the signal of vegetation change recorded in carbonate minerals preserved in the ancient soils shows the same pattern of change as the signal preserved in ancient organic matter preserved in those same soils, but the two records suggest different amounts of C4 grasses on the landscape. An intriguing outgrowth of this research is a new study exploring whether these two different tools reflect vegetation during only dry (carbonates) or wet (organic matter) times, rather than each reflecting a consistent average of vegetation across multiple drought and wet spells.  These results improve the current framework for interpreting vegetation from other geological sites around the world, where often only one tool (carbonates for example) is available.  

As for the role of climate on vegetation and small mammal population change, our combined records show a fair amount of short term variation, but no long term changes in temperature or precipitation amounts that would suggest that these factors are driving the grassland changes in this region or the changes in small mammal populations. This suggests that either internal factors are driving the changes in small mammal populations, or external factors that we have not tested here. For example, one period of pronounced change in the rodent fossil record is immediately after deposition of a thick ash. It may be that environmental changes associated with the eruption event represented by the ash could have affected the rodent communities, but occurred on a time scale that our environmental reconstructions can not resolve.
